title: A cop's dubious decisions, a shooting, and a Black man's gutsy ...
htmlTitle: A cop's dubious decisions, a shooting, and a Black man's gutsy ...
snippet: Jan 14, 2021 ... PURSUIT: Officer Joseph Ferrigno, shown in a Rochester Police Department photo taken shortly after he shot Silvon Simmons, had amassed at least ...
htmlSnippet: Jan 14, 2021 ... PURSUIT: Officer Joseph Ferrigno, shown in a Rochester Police Department photo taken shortly after he shot Silvon Simmons, had amassed at least ...

imageobject.caption: THREE BULLETS: Silvon Simmons lay bleeding in his backyard on April 1, 2016, after a cop in Rochester, New York, shot him three times from behind. The person standing over him is unidentified...
PURSUIT: Officer Joseph Ferrigno, shown in a Rochester Police Department photo taken shortly after he shot Silvon Simmons, had amassed at least 23 citizen complaints by April 1, 2016, the night...
THE SCENE: Cops descended on Immel Street in Rochester, New York, on April 1, 2016, after getting word that Officer Joseph Ferrigno was involved in a shooting. About four dozen law enforcement...
PAINFUL MEMORIES: Simmons at Immel Street, site of the shooting, in September. He said it was his first time back in the neighborhood since he was hauled away in handcuffs in an ambulance 4½...
SILENCED: After the shooting, Silvon Simmons, shown here in a photograph police saved as evidence, woke up in the hospital on a ventilator, unable to speak and flanked by uniformed Rochester police.
URGENT: Because a ventilator kept him from speaking, Silvon Simmons wrote this note to police guarding him, urging them to check him for gunshot residue. He thought that would prove his innocence.
FATEFUL ENCOUNTER: The police cruiser driven by Rochester Police Officer Joseph Ferrigno blocked the driveway next to Silvon Simmons' house on April 1, 2016 – the night Ferrigno shot Simmons...
MAPPED OUT: The cone farthest to the right in this crime scene photo shows the clothes and boots removed from Silvon Simmons in his backyard after Officer Joseph Ferrigno shot him three times...
RETURNING: Silvon Simmons points to the driveway where a Rochester police officer with a gun chased him 4½ years ago. He said his visit there with a Reuters photographer this September was...
UNION CHIEF: Michael Mazzeo, president of the Locust Club union, stood up for officers who used a spit hood, like the one Mazzeo holds here, during the deadly arrest of Daniel Prude. Jamie...
WRONG CAR: Evidence from the Silvon Simmons shooting included this photo of the Chevrolet Impala he rode in that night. Officer Joseph Ferrigno pursued the car, believing it belonged to a suspect...
THE INQUIRY: Five months after Officer Joseph Ferrigno shot Silvon Simmons, Rochester police investigators interviewed the cop about his actions that night. Showing him evidence photos like...
GUN DEBATE: Cops say Silvon Simmons fired this Ruger pistol at a Rochester police officer. No physical evidence was found linking Simmons to the gun, shown in a photo police collected as evidence.
TEST REQUEST: Silvon Simmons wore long sleeves the night he was shot, as shown in this police evidence photo. He asked that his hands and sleeves be tested for gunpowder residue, but cops never...
RESIDUAL DOUBT: During deliberations, jurors asked to review testimony about whether Silvon Simmons’ clothes were tested for gunpowder residue. This evidence photo shows the sweatshirt paramedics...
COP CULTURE: Demonstrators in September 2020 protest the death of a Black man, Daniel Prude, after an arrest in which Rochester police used a spit hood. A deputy mayor’s report about police...
UNREST: Police officers in Rochester, New York, react after flares go off during a September 4 protest over the death of Daniel Prude, a Black man who died after cops put a spit hood over his...
NICKNAME: Silvon Simmons’ parents started calling him “Tugg” after he pried apart the slats of his crib and squeezed his way out. REUTERS/Simmons family photo
SPLIT VERDICT: Silvon Simmons, in his old neighborhood in Rochester, beat the charge that he tried to kill Officer Joseph Ferrigno. But the jury found him guilty of possessing a gun found at...
SOLID BLUE: The Locust Club, founded as a social club early last century, is one of America’s oldest police unions. REUTERS/Screenshot
ON GUARD: A Rochester cop prepares for protests in September over the death of Daniel Prude. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

DRAMATIC DECISION: Judge Christopher Ciaccio stunned those in his Rochester courtroom on the day Silvon Simmons was scheduled for sentencing. Tina MacIntyre-Yee/Rochester Democrat and Chronicle/USA...
PERSEVERING: A judge sided with Rochester’s police union, ruling that the city’s new Police Accountability Board cannot compel cops to testify in investigations or impose discipline on...
VOCAL LEADER: Michael Mazzeo, chief of the Locust Club union, defended Officer Joseph Ferrigno after the Silvon Simmons shooting. Cops have dangerous jobs, he says. Jamie Germano/Rochester...
VOICES: A demonstrator raises a fist at a September protest in Rochester over the death of Daniel Prude. The fate of the city’s new police oversight board is in the hands of a New York state...
THE SPARK: The death of George Floyd beneath the knee of a police officer in Minneapolis, Minnesota, set off a summer of protest across the United States. This demonstration, in May, took place...

metatags.og:title: A cop’s dubious decisions, a shooting, and a Black man’s gutsy gamble.
metatags.og:description: A U.S. city and a powerful police union battle anew over efforts to empower residents to police the police. One man's experience exemplifies what’s at stake.

newsarticle.articlebody: Silvon Simmons was shot three times in an upstate New York city. Then he was accused of trying to kill the cop who fired at him. His story is a study in the kinds of police practices that have...

metatags.twitter:title: This video shows a man being handcuffed in 2019 and he was not an FBI
metatags.og:title: This video shows a man being handcuffed in 2019 and he was not an FBI agent, police say
metatags.og:description: A video has been viewed millions of times in multiple Facebook and Twitter posts in early June 2020 alongside a claim it shows the arrest of a black FBI agent. The posts were published after nationwide protests against police brutality and systemic racism broke out across the US. The claim is false; US police said the man in the video is not an FBI agent, adding the clip shows an incident in June 2019.
metatags.twitter:creator: @afpfactuel
